text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

There's very few places
in the world where

you get to be 22, 23 years old
leading a group through team

formation, building, and
ultimately a deployment
in support of our nation--

in my case, in support of
the campaign against ISIS.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

We were fully deployed
in the Persian Gulf.

I had 30 seconds to
decide whether or not
to shut down the reactor.

By shutting it down
I might jeopardize

the lives of the pilots that
were launching and landing

on the ship, or by keeping
it operational, of course,
I risk everybody.

It was a last second
deployment for Hurricane Irma
back in September 2017.

It's 420 miles wide,
185 mile an hour winds

barreling down on the state of
Florida, and all of a sudden I

have to fly a helicopter onto
the back of a Coast Guard
cutter.

Really understanding
people's fears or concerns
of the unknown--
bridging that human gap--

throughout my time
in the military

I learned a lot about humans
and how we process change.
So I wanted to be on the ground.

I was part of the
first group of women

to be with these
all-male combat units,

and they had never
worked with women before.

We had attached to a
battalion of commandos.

We were training,
advising, and then we

would take them out
conducting combat operations
against the Taliban.

I had to find a way to manage
13 civilian interpreters who
were local Afghans.

The complexity here was that
they were mission critical.

We could not do our job
if they didn't show up.
[MUSIC PLAYING]

In any role that you're
in in the military you're

leading people, you're
leading projects,

you're leading a lot of
different stakeholders.

When I joined the military
everyone was like, why?
It's not a 9 to 5 job.

You don't hang up the
uniform and go home at night.

It becomes who you are, and
you give so much of yourself

for the mission that our country
and democracy is built upon.

When you're facing
uncertainty, that

is what training and
preparation is for.

That is why military
teams spend years

training to execute something
that will take moments.

You operate at your
highest version of yourself

when you invest
in the development
and growth of others.

So we have a saying
in the military--

it goes, "Mission
first, people always."

From my experience, it's
"People first, mission always."

Because sometimes where we
can make the biggest impact

is taking care of the people
so that they have what

they need to
accomplish the mission.

How do you process through
challenging, complex problems

with multiple stakeholders
in a chaotic and uncertain
environment?

I saw business school
as an opportunity
to make the biggest impact.

Managing a team in
government, managing

a team in the military, managing
a team in the private sector--
everyone has needs.

The business
education has given me

a strategic outlook
and perspective

on how to design where
we need to be going.

Something to keep in mind
is that less than 10%

of the adult US
population is a veteran.

Being an immigrant, it
was important for me

to give back to a country
that has given my family

opportunities that
we wouldn't have had.

My parents immigrated from India
and emphasize the importance
of giving back to this nation.

And I am extremely
grateful for all of those
that are continuing to serve.

What if we didn't have
service men and women putting

in everything they could
during World War II?
What would that look like?

What would it look like if we
didn't have an all volunteer

force and we would
be drafting people
for the global war on terrorism?
What would that look like?

So I would just ask for everyone
to take a moment to reflect,

because there are
people fighting

for all of the freedoms that
you get to take advantage of.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
